Comment: You are correct. The elephant in the room is too much for the nation to fully comprehend because it would start a panic.   Economies with substantial reserves of US Treasury bonds , particularly China and Japan , are forced into accessing these for economic stimulus and support payments.  This is the whole purpose of bond and gold reserves. When economic conditions deteriorate then these nations must draw on reserves to protect economies.  When the US is no longer seen as a safe store of wealth it then provides more impetus to draw down on reserves. Especially so when the US is the source of this economic turmoil.  This also deflates the value of the USD and increases sovereign risk of default on the tens of trillions in US debt. It can spark a downward spiral in confidence.  Economies may soon decide that it better to jettison US Treasury bonds while they retain some value and avoid being left holding the baby.   A crashed bond market and USD will make the US unable to extract itself from economic recession as it has done before.   Without an attractive store of capital it will have enormous difficulty in raising capital for national investment and stimulus.   Should it default then it will throw the global economy into a deep recession or depression.

Comment: China's currency will be volatile until it is not. The opposite of what is happening with the US dollar. Also BRICS.  > The dollar's reign is slowly coming to an end. Economic sanctions imposed by the U.S. are contributing to de-dollarization efforts, which may lead to a prolonged depreciation of the dollar. >  > The yuan, China's currency, is gaining traction as a potential alternative to the dollar. According to the IMF, 46 economies had allocated more than 5% of foreign exchange reserve assets to the yuan or to currencies outside the basket of "special drawing rights" currencies by the end of 2020. >  > The yuan is expected to gradually overtake the British pound and the Japanese yen in terms of payments, transactions, and reserves if China's economy improves after the second half of this year. Institutional reform progress will also be crucial for the yuan's growth. >  > Digital currencies, including cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, are vying for a slice of the dollar's pie. China's digital yuan has sparked a de-dollarization debate, and its usage is being rolled out gradually in China.

Comment: You can buy bread with silver. A silver dime is (currently) worth $2.50 or equal to a loaf of bread. Upside, silver is more liquid than gold. Downside is silver is not a good hedge against inflation - b/c its value is greatly influenced by industrial demand, which declines in a recession.
